title: What is the difference between the reaction of potassium and sodium with water? - Quora

response.answer_text: First difference: Potassium reacts more vigourously and explosively with water while Sodium reacts less violently with water when compared to potassium. Second difference: Although both Group I metals form metal hydroxides when reacted with water, however, they form Sodium Hydroxide (for sodium metal) and hydrogen gas, and potassium hydroxide(for potassium metal) and hydrogen gas respectively.

The reaction of potassium metal with water is far more VIGOROUS than the reaction between water, and sodium metal…. [math]K(s) + H_{2}O(l) \longrightarrow KOH(aq) + \dfrac{1}{2}H_{2}(g)\uparrow[/math] SMALL quantities of sodium metal, when added to water, will react vigorously, but you are unlikely to see flames. Addition of potassium WILL produce flames, especially when the dihydrogen combusts… And I hope you have seen these reactions in the laboratory… With ethyl alcohol, you can destroy LARGE masses of sodium metal with reasonable safety according to the reaction… [math]H_{3}C-CH_{2}OH(l) +Na(s) \longrightarrow H_{3}C-CH_{2}O^{-}Na^{+} +\dfrac{1}{2}H_{2}(g)\uparrow[/math] You do not attempt this with potassium metal … a fire will result … other strategies are employed to destroy potassium residues…
